Around Gyeongju Asian Games Stadium

Bulguksa Public Parking Lot

Tourist attractions that are good to look around together

Yangdong Village

31 minutes by car from Guncheon Station (closed)

It was formed by Wolseong Son and Yeogang Lee as the largest clan village in Korea that retains the traditional culture and nature of the Joseon Dynasty.

Gyori Gimbap Bonghwangdaejeom

19 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 6 minutes' drive

Representative menu: Gimbap, Banquet Noodles
Headquarters: 22 minutes by car from Bulguksa Temple
Bomun Branch: 2 minutes' walk from Bomun Tourist Complex

Gyeongju Daereungwon

22 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 5 minutes' drive

These tombs are located in the area of Nodong-dong, the center of Gyeongju, and include Bonghwangdae/Sikrichong/Geumryeongchong.

Cheomseongdae

26 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 5 minutes' drive

It is believed to have been built during the 27th Queen Seondeok of Silla and is one of the landmarks that symbolizes Gyeongju

the Imperial Palace and Wolji

30 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 8 minutes' drive

It is the site of the royal palace of Silla. As it was used as a royal palace where the prince lived, it is said that a banquet was held when the country was celebrated or when he greeted precious guests.

Hwangseong Park (McMun-dong)

31 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) and 4 minutes' drive

It is a park in the northern part of Gyeongju and used as a training ground for galleries during the Silla Period

Woljeong Bridge

35 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 8 minutes' drive

It was built during the Unified Silla Period, and what was lost during the Joseon Dynasty was restored as the largest wooden bridge in Korea in April 2018.

The Richest House (Gyochon Village)

35 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 8 minutes' drive

The house of Gyeongju Choi, a packed house.
Gyeongju's richest man set an example of Korean capitalism by continuing his wealth and honor for 12 to 400 years.

bunhwang temple

42 minutes' walk from Gyeongju Station (closed) 8 minutes' drive

It is the branch temple of Bulguksa Temple, the headquarters of the 11th parish of the Jogye Order of Korean Buddhism. Bunhwangsa Temple is also famous for its Mojeon Stone Pagoda, which is connected to Hwangnyongsa Temple Site and is designated as a national treasure.

Bomun Lake

1 minute walk from Bomun Tourist Complex

An artificial lake of 500,000 pyeong built under the old fortress site of Myeonghwalsan Mountain in the east of Gyeongju City under the development plan of the Gyeongju Bomun Tourist Complex

Bomunjeong Pavilion

11 minutes' walk from Bomun Tourist Complex

It boasts such a beautiful scenery that it has been introduced as a "Korean Scenic View" on CNN.

Gyeongju World & California Beach

20 minutes' walk from Bomun Tourist Complex and 2 minutes' drive

Gyeongju World Amusement can also enjoy a popular water park "California Beach" in summer and a large-scale snow park in winter.

Gyeongju World Expo Cultural Park

29 minutes' walk from Bomun Tourist Complex and 4 minutes' drive

Launched in 1998 as the world's first international cultural fair on culture and arts, it has held 10 global events until 2019

Namsan Seonseonam Rock-carved Bodhisattva Ban Sang

23 minutes by car from Bulguksa

The 1.4m-high Rock-carved Bodhisattva statue is carved on the southern rock straight above Chilbulam Rock.

Columnar joint (Yangnam-myeon)

36 minutes by car from Bulguksa

Columnar joints developed along the coast of Eupcheon-ri, Yangnam-myeon
